title: When settlers came to the United States, wouldn’t it have been easier for them to just start occupying Russia? Why was it necessary to travel to North America? - Quora
tags: Russia and the United States of America

Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Er, that’s exactly what happened. Russia expanded eastwards into Siberia and Central Asia at more or less the same time Western Europeans started to colonise North America, and with similar techniques of colonial settlement and subversion/resettlement of native tribes. And the Russians invited and allowed Central Europeans, particularly Germans, to settle in Russian territory, so you got Mennonites in Pennsylvania, and settled on the Volga for example. One of the great unreported horrors at the end of WW2 was the forced “repatriation” of hundreds of thousands of ethnic Germans from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, people who hadn’t actually lived in Germany for hundreds of years. For Western Europeans, a sea voyage to America was less of an ordeal than a land/river voyage to the Russian Steppe, and with far less cultural acclimatization involved.

Russia almost always was known for harsh winters and lack of infrastructures. The European part was more or less civilized thanks to Peter the Great but the rest was really wild and uneducated. Even if today someone will be offered free land in far east I think he or she will pass. US however was created mainly based on European laws (municipal at least) and East coast was not much different from Europe itself. Conquering the west was different story, called gold rush. People in search of free land with gold in mind conquered the West coast. If you look at California’s nature and weather it is very close to perfect (for me at least).

Much of what would become the United States has a hospitable climate. Much of Russia will have you frozen solid within a minute. The largest populations are closer to borders of other countries, and in ports. But for a good portion of Siberia, there’s only the native folk hardened to it.

Russia was a backwards feudal society, with no opportunities for immigrants. Hard work in Russia only got you more hard work, oppression from the Tsarist Okhrana (secret police). If you were Jewish, there were periodic pogroms. What could possibly motivate any European to pick up and move to Russia?
